A Blackbox in the Car ?

US road planners are looking for a source of money to repair the declining high-way system , and believe that the solution has been found in a small black box that can be placed on the armature board of every car .

The equipment that record every kilometre driven and report information to the authorities is at the heart of a controversial attempt by Washington and state planning offices to revise the obsolete system for financing US roads .
The normally boring area of road planning has suddenly created an intensive debate with colourful alliances .

Libertarians have joined environmental groups and argue that the government can use small boxes to record the kilometres driven – and possibly also where they have been driven – and then use the information to calculate tax models .
The Tea Party is horrified .
The American Civil Rights Association ( ACLU ) is also deeply concerned and expresses a number of concerns about data protection .
But , while Congress cannot agree on action , several states are no longer waiting .
They are currently checking how they can switch over the next ten years to a system where drivers pay per mile driven .
Thousands of drivers have already tested the tachographs , some of which have GPS monitoring .
This is really a must for our country .

“ It is nothing we may only use , ” said Hasan Ikhrata , Managing Director of Southern California Assn. of Governments , who plans to record the miles driven by all Californian drivers in the state from 2025 .
The way we pay these taxes will change .
The technology for this is there .
The initiative comes at a time when the Highway Trust Fund , funded from taxes paid to US Americans at the fuel column , is broken .
But America is no longer getting as much in the way it used to .
Cars use less petrol .
The government mineral oil tax of 18.4 cents per gallon ( less than 4 Eurocent per litre ) has not increased for 20 years .
Politicians do not dare to raise the tax by just one cent at high injection prices .
“ The gasoline tax is simply not future-proof , ” Lee Munich said , an expert on transport legislation at the University of Minnesota .
His federal state has recently equipped 500 cars with tachographs to test a mile-based payment system .
“ This is the longer-term most useful alternative , ” he said .
Bureaucrats call it a mile-based user fee .

It is not surprising that the idea is supported by urban liberals , for example , because the tax could be used to influence driving behaviour in such a way as to reduce congestion and climate-damaging exhaust gases .
California ’ s planners rely on the system to draw up strategies to achieve the Federal State ’ s ambitious , legally anchored goals on climate change .
But the Republican Bill Shuster from Pennsylvania , Chairman of the House Transportation Committee , also stated that he was the most viable long-term alternative .
The Reason Foundation ’ s freelance marketers are also enthusiastic about the idea of letting drivers pay on a journey .
“ This is not a tax that disappears in a black hole , ” says Adrian Moore , Vice President of Reason , for directives .
People pay directly for what they get .
The movement is also supported by two former US Transport Ministers who , in a report in 2011 , called on Congress to move toward mile-based settlement .
Last year , the US Senate approved a $ 90 million pilot project , comprising 10,000 cars .

But the majority in the House of Representatives prevented the push , responding to the concerns of rural MEPs who represent people who often have to go many miles on their way to work or to the city in everyday life .
Several states and large cities are nevertheless moving in that direction in their own fashion .
Oregon , who currently has 5,000 drivers , is most committed to the country ’ s biggest experiment .
These drivers will soon pay the mileage fees to the federal state instead of the petroleum tax .
Nevada has already completed a pilot project .
New York City is also considering such a move .
Illinois tests it to a limited extent with trucks .

And the I-95 coalition , which includes the Transport Ministries of 17 states on the east coast ( including Maryland , Pennsylvania , Virginia , and Florida ) , is currently examining how to introduce the change . the and the the . the the the the the the the the the the the .
The concept is not a universal hit .
In Nevada , where 50 volunteers were recently equipped with the equipment , drivers were sceptical about the idea that the government could pursue any of its movements .
“ Concerns about Big Brother and such things were a major problem , ” says Alauddin Khan , head of strategy and earnings management in the Nevada Transport Ministry .
People did not want it .
When the test started , Nevada ’ s ACLU warned on its website : “ It would be relatively easy to turn the tachograph into adult monitoring devices . ”
There is no need to build a massive technological infrastructure that would inevitably be used to collect data on the daily movements of individuals .
Nevada is part of a series of states that are now looking for affordable technology that will allow the state to capture the driven kilometres , but not exactly when and where .
That , Khan argues , would also reassure the public .
Hunting for this technology has led some authorities to a small startup company called True Mileage in California .
The company did not originally intend to help states tax drivers .
Rather , their aim was to take root in an emerging market for car insurance , where drivers should pay on the basis of the miles driven .
However , the equipment it tests is also interesting for road planners , because they do not work with GPS and provide only limited information that is regularly uploaded by modem .
“ People are more willing to participate if their speed and location are not recorded , ” said Ryan Morrison , Managing Director of True Mileage .

Remote planets , gravitational waves or black holes - experts from the European Space Agency must now agree on two major projects they want to launch in the next few years .

The choice is difficult : Do you want to search for gravitational waves ?
Or rather explore the origin of cosmos ?
Or searching for earth-like planets and discovering alien life ?
These are the questions that are being asked by the European Space Agency Esa .
For their " Cosmic Vision " program , they are looking for ideas for two major space projects , which are intended to make the research decisive .
The budget for such " L missions " is approximately EUR 1 billion .
The start is expected to be 2028 and 2034 .
In early September , the elite of European space research met in Paris to discuss proposals for such missions .
30 ideas were discussed and five of them have now come to a closer choice .
Many bodies examined the proposals and followed up with researchers .
A final decision will be taken by the scientific programme committee in the next few days .
Overall four major questions have been selected by the Esa , to which the missions of the 2007 programme " Cosmic Vision " should find answers .
What are the conditions for the emergence of planets and lives ?
The exact steps in the emergence of stars from large gas clouds - and hence the emergence of planets surrounding these stars - are still in the proverbial dark .
A big infrared telescope in all could get through this dark .
And if a star owns the planet under which circumstances can life arise there ?
To investigate this question , the 2017 space telescope " Cheops " will be launched , which will examine more closely the 500 already known planet systems in our neighbourhood .
However , the opportunities are limited , Cheops is a small mission with a budget of EUR 150 million .

With larger instruments , astronomers could map earth-like planets and even analyze the composition of their atmospheres , searching for " biomarkers " : gases that are considered to be an indication of biological activity .
How does the solar system work ?
This question , too , should ultimately provide an insight into the conditions for the emergence of life .
The magnetic activity of a star and the interaction of its magnetic field as well as its particle radiation with the planet system plays an important role .
In our solar system , these processes can be examined exemplary .
With the " Solar Orbiter " , Esa has already approved a M-Class mission ( where the budget is about half a billion euros ) for this issue .
The probe should start in 2017 and watch the surface and activity of the sun carefully .
Jupiter and his moons are also of great interest to researchers .
They want to find out what role the giant planet played in the development of the solar system .
For this , Esa provides for the first of the three L missions of the " Cosmic Vision " program .
The song " Juice " ( Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer ) will start in 2022 .
Eight years later , she reaches Jupiter and is intended to examine the atmosphere of the planet and the icy moons of Europe , Kallisto and Ganymed .
What are the basic physical laws of the universe ?
The everyday world offers many opportunities to study matter under extreme conditions and to examine whether the laws of nature we know are still valid there .
Perhaps there are also deviations that could guide the physicists to a new theory under which all known laws of nature can be united .
How did the universe emerge and what is it made of ?
Our cosmos came through the big bang 13.7 billion years ago .

In addition to the common matter of stars , planets and living creatures like us , there are dark matter whose gravity holds galaxies and galaxies together , and Dark Energy , which accelerates the expansion of the space .
So far , researchers do not know which physical laws were valid in the first second fractions of the urban band , nor what dark matter and dark energy consist of .
